name: (2E)-1,3-benzothiazol-2-yl[(4-chlorophenyl)hydrazono]ethanenitrile
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1084
Reason: 1,3-Benzothiazole has a melting point around 106°C. The presence of two phenyl groups and one chlorine atom can significantly increase the melting point due to the potential for hydrogen bonding and dipole-dipole interactions. Each phenyl group may contribute around +30 to +50°C. The chlorine atom introduces a strong withdrawing group, increasing intermolecular forces and melting point by approximately +50°C. The hydrazono group introduces additional rigid structures that can participate in dipole interactions and potentially hydrogen bonding, raising the melting point by about +70°C. The thiazole ring introduces additional rigid structures that can participate in dipole interactions and potentially hydrogen bonding, raising the melting point by about +50°C. Summing up these changes: Two phenyl groups and one chlorine atom contribute approximately +60°C, the hydrazono group at +70°C, and the thiazole ring at +50°C.
